{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3585870,"name":"Zack","username":"zkay","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/z/71e660/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-10T00:42:38.870Z","cooked":"

My team has this 4 pin LED strip, but I just realized it doesn’t plug directly into the roborio. We are using an Orange Pi 5 running Photonvision, and were hoping we could also use it to control the LEDs. Is it possible to do both things at the same time?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-10T00:42:38.870Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":16,"reads":163,"readers_count":162,"score":112.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":498626,"topic_slug":"controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi","display_username":"Zack","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.andymark.com/products/12v-individually-addressable-led-light-strip-16-4-ft","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"12V Individually Addressable LED Light Strip 16.4 ft - AndyMark, Inc","clicks":17}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57641,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi/498626/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3585911,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-10T01:43:52.427Z","cooked":"

Those can be controlled directly off the rio, and is likely the easiest way to do so. See here:

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Addressable LEDs

LED strips have been commonly used by teams for several years for a variety of reasons. They allow teams to debug robot functionality from the audience, provide a visual marker for their robot, and...

The main trick is that you have to power them using a 12V source (such as a PDH port), but use your roborio’s PWM signal pin. So you wind up with a bit of odd wiring.

The Orange Pi/Photonvision also cannot power them, so that doesn’t help. You technically can provide signals to them from here, but this is a very non-trivial process, and much more challenging than just using the rio for it.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-10T01:43:52.427Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":149,"readers_count":148,"score":54.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":498626,"topic_slug":"controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/hardware-apis/misc/addressable-leds.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Addressable LEDs — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi/498626/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3586146,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-10T12:51:32.360Z","cooked":"
tekdemo:

So you wind up with a bit of odd wiring.

No more odd than powering a long 5V strip since the roboRIO can’t handle that load either and actually it’s less odd than our need for a 12v to 5v convertor which OP won’t have to have.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-10T12:51:32.360Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":114,"readers_count":113,"score":27.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":498626,"topic_slug":"controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi/498626/3","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3586519,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-10T16:36:28.926Z","cooked":"

I mean it’s odd as in there’s no single, well defined connection point for it, which OP seemed to be looking for. Most other FRC wiring has precisely color coded 1:1 connections and good wiring guides. That’s not exactly true for LED strips unless you’re using one of the optional third party routes.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-10T16:36:28.926Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":81,"readers_count":80,"score":16.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":498626,"topic_slug":"controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":24594,"username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi/498626/4","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3586832,"name":"Zack","username":"zkay","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/z/71e660/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-10T18:20:42.506Z","cooked":"

Thanks, how would I use the signal pin exactly? The plug on the LED strip has 4 wires but they are connected together at the end with plastic, so I physically can’t plug it into the PWM port. Will I have to separate the wires and redo the connector?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-10T18:21:30.982Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":64,"readers_count":63,"score":12.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":498626,"topic_slug":"controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi","display_username":"Zack","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":44763,"username":"tekdemo","name":"Dan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57641,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi/498626/5","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3586934,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-10T18:40:17.418Z","cooked":"

Oh man, Andymark’s documentation for these sucks. This should help:

image1456×1199 45.4 KB

The 12V power and ground go to the PDH or other 12V power source. You’d preferably want to use a more stable 12V power source than the PDH, but I’m not sure what you have available, and this will get you moving.

The DI goes to the Rio’s pwm signal pin (any one is fine, you select it in code for the AddressableLED class).

The BI pin is “backup input”, which is used to jump the signal past broken LEDs. This gets the same input as the DI, so just connect BI and DI together. This can be done with a solder blob, a jumper wire, or splice in your wire (whatever is easier).

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-10T18:41:40.615Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":59,"readers_count":58,"score":31.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":498626,"topic_slug":"controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi/498626/6","reactions":[{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3587045,"name":"Zack","username":"zkay","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/z/71e660/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-10T18:58:51.859Z","cooked":"

Awesome, I’ll try this next week!

@tekdemo shows the proper connections and just to help make sure nothing goes wrong - notice the LED strip is directional and you are about to perform delicate surgery on the tail end of the arrow where the strip starts with the BI, DI. If there is a connector on the arrow head > end of the strip, it’s for extending with another strip.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-10T20:04:59.792Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":42,"readers_count":41,"score":8.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":498626,"topic_slug":"controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57641,"username":"zkay","name":"Zack","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/z/71e660/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi/498626/8","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3587284,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-10T20:27:49.818Z","cooked":"

Just to add slightly more context: It’s kind of delicate surgery to get a jointed soldered on there, but don’t panic. It should be pretty robust against inexperience. In most cases where you screw something up, the closest LED might die but the rest should work thanks to the backup pin. In the worst case, you just cut off the nearest LED and try again. Strips are easy like that.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-10T20:27:49.818Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":37,"readers_count":36,"score":12.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":498626,"topic_slug":"controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/controlling-leds-and-running-photonvision-on-one-orange-pi/498626/9","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3587385,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-10T21:40:27.223Z","cooked":"
tekdemo:

worst case

That often happened with my team - it’s not a rare case with beginner soldering students. Don’t cut the strip to the desired final length until you have it working with the new connectors. But then again the worst case is the strip is a little short but nobody will notice (and you can extend the strip now that you know how).
